channel.title: Comments on: Interpolation of heat maps

item.title: By: Malte
item.dc:creator: Malte
item.description: I can write the data of my map plot into a file by using "set table". However, this does only work without an interpolation. Is there a way to write the interpolated points and values into a file?
item.content:encoded: I can write the data of my map plot into a file by using “set table”. However, this does only work without an interpolation. Is there a way to write the interpolated points and values into a file?

item.title: By: Martin
item.dc:creator: Martin
item.description: I don't know if it by design or something funny happens when 2d projection is done, but you feed 6x6 matrix and what is plotted in Figure 1 is a 5x5 matrix (even when not interpolated) -- I actually need all col and rows -- any idea how to fix it? I tried pretty much every combination of plot/splot paramters, but it is not working ( I have ugly workaround by setting xrange to a range slightly longer+taller and offsetting from set xrange [0:5] to set xrange[-0.5, 5.5]. Thanks
item.content:encoded: I don’t know if it by design or something funny happens when 2d projection is done, but you feed 6×6 matrix and what is plotted in Figure 1 is a 5×5 matrix (even when not interpolated) — I actually need all col and rows — any idea how to fix it? I tried pretty much every combination of plot/splot paramters, but it is not working ( I have ugly workaround by setting xrange to a range slightly longer+taller and offsetting from set xrange [0:5] to set xrange[-0.5, 5.5]. Thanks

item.title: By: Lam
item.dc:creator: Lam
item.description: I tried to plot this txt file (http://1drv.ms/1P22zYh). while it does plot it correctly with the command stated in the above article, the plot is upside down. while i could invert the diagram, but then the axis would invert as well. what could possibly be the reason for this?
item.content:encoded: I tried to plot this txt file (http://1drv.ms/1P22zYh). while it does plot it correctly with the command stated in the above article, the plot is upside down. while i could invert the diagram, but then the axis would invert as well. what could possibly be the reason for this?

item.title: By: Rose
item.dc:creator: Rose
item.description: Thanks for a great tutorial! I was frantically looking for a way to make something like a Mathematica density plot in Gnuplot, and this is the only place I could find such a thing. Three cheers!
item.content:encoded: Thanks for a great tutorial! I was frantically looking for a way to make something like a Mathematica density plot in Gnuplot, and this is the only place I could find such a thing. Three cheers!

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jorge.

If your data is in the right format it is straightforward. Just remove the matrix option and plot it with

splot 'heat_map_data.txt'

The rest of the code should be the same.

item.title: By: Jorge
item.dc:creator: Jorge
item.description: How I can make an interpolation to smooth my image if my "heat-map" was generated from a file X, Y, Z?
item.content:encoded: How I can make an interpolation to smooth my image if my “heat-map” was generated from a file X, Y, Z?

item.content:encoded: […] documentation (which was AMAZING by the way), I was able to figure out that I wanted to make a heat map using an image file format.  I worked off the examples given and was able to get a batch file […]

item.title: By: robin
item.dc:creator: robin
item.description: Be very carefull with the use of pm3d for matrix representation !!!! As it's written in GNUPLOT manual, with the plot command and a M x N matrix, you will have a surface of M x N elements. This is different from the pm3d plotting style, where an M x N set of data will form a surface of (M-1) x (N-1) elements.
item.content:encoded:
Be very carefull with the use of pm3d for matrix representation !!!!
As it’s written in GNUPLOT manual, with the plot command and a M x N matrix, you will have a surface of M x N elements. This is different from the pm3d plotting style, where an M x N set of data will form a surface of (M-1) x (N-1) elements.

item.title: By: mght
item.dc:creator: mght
item.description: I'm pretty sure it is bilinear. As you can see such changes clearly along the main axis in Fig. 3 (horizontal and vertical) indicating the plains were interpolating with two constant directional vector x and y for each plain. (From the given point, the interpolated data is radially symmetric along both axis).
item.content:encoded: I’m pretty sure it is bilinear. As you can see such changes clearly along the main axis in Fig. 3 (horizontal and vertical) indicating the plains were interpolating with two constant directional vector x and y for each plain. (From the given point, the interpolated data is radially symmetric along both axis).

item.title: By: Zach
item.dc:creator: Zach
item.description: I believe it is bicubic. I ran into an issue with overshoot from interpolation with pm3d plots. This indicates that it's not linear. Can someone verify or refute this?
item.content:encoded: I believe it is bicubic. I ran into an issue with overshoot from interpolation with pm3d plots. This indicates that it’s not linear. Can someone verify or refute this?
